variant.question: The operational regulations regarding scheduled performance are contained in the following document

options.text: EASA AIR OPS
EASA CS-25
EASA CS-23
FAR-25

variant.question: Based on regulation (EU) **965/2012**, the LVO procedures which are to be set by the operator are:

options.text: Taxi, Take-off, Approach, Flare, Landing, Rollout, Missed approach procedure.
Taxi, Take-off, Holding, Approach, Landing, Rollout, Missed approach procedure.
Taxi, Approach, Landing, Missed approach procedure only.
Take-off, Approach, Landing, Missed approach procedure only.

variant.question: The operator shall only conduct CAT II operations if:

options.text: the DH is determined by means of a radio altimeter and the flight crew consists of at least two pilots
the DH is determined by means of a radio altimeter and the flight crew consists of at least one pilots
the DH is determined by means of a barometric altimeter and the flight crew consists of at least two pilots
the DH is determined by means of a barometric altimeter and the flight crew consists of at least one pilot

variant.question: What does COMMISSION REGULATION (EU) No 965/2012 of 5 October 2012 apply to?

options.text: Commercial air transport operations with aeroplanes and helicopters, including ramp inspections of aircraft of operators under the safety oversight of another State when landed at aerodromes located in the territory subject to the provisions of the Treaty.
Air operations with all aircraft of operators located in the territory subject to the provisions of the Treaty.

Air operations with aeroplanes, helicopters, balloonsand sailplanes, including ramp inspections of aircraft of operators under the safety oversight of another State when landed at aerodromes located in the territory subject to the provisions of the Treaty, including military, police and customs air operations.

Air operations with aeroplanes, helicopters, balloons and sailplanes, including ramp inspections of aircraft of operators under the safety oversight of another State when landed at aerodromes located in the territory subject to the provisions of the Treaty.

variant.question: The operator shall only conduct CAT II, OTS CAT II or CAT III operations if:

options.text: all height call-outs below 200 ft above the aerodrome threshold elevation are determined by a radio altimeter.
all height call-outs below 200 ft above the aerodrome elevation are determined by a radio altimeter.
all height call-outs below 500 ft above the aerodrome elevation are determined by a radio altimeter.
all height call-outs below 500 ft above the aerodrome threshold elevation are determined by a radio altimeter.

variant.question: Annex III of EU regulation 965/**2012** is entitled ORO. What do the initials ORO stand for?

options.text: Organisation Requirements of Air Operations.
Operational Requirements for Commercial Air Operations.
Organisation of Route Operations.
Operational Route Organisation.

variant.question: A CAT operator requires specialist work (which falls under the scope of the CAT operator’s approval) to be carried out by an outside contractor. Which of the following options is correct?

options.text: A written agreement should exist between the operator and the contracted organisation.
An oral and written agreement should exist between the operator and the contracted organisation.
An oral agreement should exist between the operator and the contracted organisation.
No need for agreement between the operator and the contracted organisation.

variant.question: A CAT operator holds an approval to carry out certain activities, but is currently unable to cope with the amount of work to be undertaken. The operator therefore decides to contract out some of the work to another operator, with the same level of approval. Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: The operator’s compliance monitoring should check that the subcontructor’s approval effectively covers the contracted activities and that it is still valid.
The type of subcontracting arrangement described is prohibited by the applicable regulations.
Irrespective of the level of approval held by the subcontractor, the work shall be carried out under the approval of the operator contracting work.
There is NO need to check on the subcontractor’s approval, authorisation procedures.

variant.question: A CAT operator requires specialist work (which falls under the scope of the CAT operator’s approval) to be carried out by an outside contractor. The contractor’s approval to do these activities has NOT yet been granted by the competent authority. Is it still possible for the contractor to undertake the work for the operator?

options.text: Yes, under the approval and oversight of the operator as a subcontracted activity.
Yes, provided the contractor obtains individual approvals for their employees undertaking the work, and agrees with the operator to take full responsibility for the work, in writing.
No, because the overall responsibility for the work rests with the contractor, the contractor must have received their approval.
No, this work must be done by the operator because it falls under the scope of their approval.
